awd_titl_txt: GP-EXTRA: Lab Camp: An inclusive, accessible alternative to field-based geoscience capstone courses
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1
Despite decades of work on diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) at the national level, the geosciences remain the least diverse of STEM fields. Welcoming geoscientists with diverse backgrounds and abilities into this field requires multi-directional action by all members of geology departments. The Geology Department at Western Washington University (WWU) seeks to develop its capacity to address issues of DEI through several targeted interventions. In order to build a more inclusive Geology Department at WWU, we will create a comprehensive
program consisting of five components: 1) Development of a new Lab Camp capstone course option in addition to traditional Field Camp; 2) Ongoing renovation of the Field Camp capstone to make the course more accessible; 3) Workshops for graduate student Teaching Assistants
focused on inclusive teaching practices; 4) Professional development opportunities for WWU Geology faculty focused on DEI; and 5) Department seminar speakers who focus on topics related to DEI. This program emphasizes the development of a new Lab Camp because doing
so will create a more accessible alternative to the traditional Field Camp model and it will provide students with opportunities to develop high-impact lab-based research skills that are increasingly valuable in geoscience professions. Creating a more inclusive and accessible department will result in the recruitment and retention of a more diverse population of undergraduate and graduate students. Once implemented, this model for change can be adapted and transferred to other geology programs nationwide.

Part 2
Field Camp is the most common form of capstone course offered in undergraduate geoscience programs in the United States. About half of all geoscience students participate in some version of field camp while earning their bachelor's degree, and those who do not are often encouraged to participate in other types of field experiences. Most undergraduate geoscience programs also emphasize learning in the field by including a range of field experiences in regular coursework. However, little research has been conducted on the learning benefits of field-based geoscience capstone courses. This project will examine the learning benefits of field camp capstone courses
by (1) characterizing the educational impact of field-based and lab-based courses and (2) comparing the two experiences. To evaluate this, we will use pre- and post-course assessments of learning gains. The research team will also measure accessibility and inclusion in field and lab camp courses by leading students in ongoing qualitative analysis activities. Focus groups and interviews will be used to evaluate the impact of the program on faculty and graduate student instructors? views on accessibility and inclusion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2019, a team of faculty in the Geology Department at Western Washington University (WWU) were awarded a grant from the National Science Foundation (NSF-1911615) to develop the Department's capacity to address issues of accessibility, diversity, equity, and inclusion (ADEI) through the creation of a new capstone course for geoscience majors. This course, Lab Camp, focused on lab-based research skills rather than the field-based skills featured in the department’s existing capstone course, Field Camp. It was also designed with accessibility and inclusivity in mind so that students who are unable to commit to a six-week field course could complete an equivalent capstone course. After the course was first offered in Summer 2023, university-level budget restrictions and department capacity limitations led to the course being put on indefinite hiatus, with hope that aspects of the course will be implemented in the future.

The Need for An Alternative: Field Camp is the most common form of capstone course offered in undergraduate geoscience programs in the United States. About half of all geoscience students participate in some version of field camp while earning their bachelor's degree, and those who do not are often encouraged to participate in other types of field experiences. Field camp performs an important role in the development of students' identity as geoscientists because it requires them to spend several weeks doing research with other students, faculty and professionals (Petcovic et al., 2014; Mogk & Goodwin, 2012; Elkins & Elkins, 2007). In fact, field camp is sometimes considered a de facto boot camp, an experience that pushes students to their intellectual, physical, and emotional limits. While this type of challenging environment helps some students bond and grow into their newfound geoscientist identity together, the same environment can alienate other students, especially those from minoritized groups. For this reason, field camp is considered one of the many reasons that the geosciences attract far fewer students from underrepresented groups than other STEM fields (Bernard & Cooperdock, 2018). With this context in mind, we developed Lab Camp, a more accessible and inclusive capstone course alternative to Field Camp that met the same learning and professional development outcomes.

Lab Camp: A More Accessible and Inclusive Capstone Course: Lab Camp course was designed to be a six-week, modular program hosted at WWU's Shannon Point Marine Center (SPMC) in Anacortes, WA. Students lived together in the dorms at SPMC and studied the local geology through a source to sinkapproach that began with a tectonic module focused on the North Cascades, followed sediment flow in a quaternary geomorphology module, and ended with a marine sedimentology module in the Salish Sea. Ten students participated in the inaugural offering of the course in Summer 2023.

We studied student learning outcomes and experiences via pre- and post-course surveys offered to students in both Lab and Field Camp. A comparison of the two populations showed that student learning outcomes were equivalent. Students in both courses self-reported similar levels of mastery of the skills and practices shared between the two courses. We also measured the strength of students’ geoscience identity and found that students in both courses experienced a similar rise in geoscience identity score. These results suggest that a lab-based capstone course fulfills the same goals and outcomes as a field-based course. The other major result of this survey centers on accessibility. The students who opted to take our Lab Camp course did so for a range of legitimate reasons, ranging from needing access to medical care to family obligations that were eased by the ability to return home on the weekends. Furthermore, nearly half of all students in both Lab Camp and Field Camp self-identified as disabled in some way, a rate much higher than perceived by faculty. At WWU, this information has spurred discussion around ways to improve the accessibility of our ongoing Field Camp course, and recommend that departments across the country take these same factors into consideration.
